column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0035] Arc spraying is similar to flame spraying, but the power source is different.
#Text=Instead of depending on a combustion flame, arc spraying derives its energy from an electric arc.
#Text=Two wires, composed of the metallic coating material and carrying DC electric current, touch together at their tips.
#Text=The energy that releases, when the two wires touch, heats and melts the wire, while a stream of gas deposits the molten metal onto the surface of the substrate, creating a metal layer.
#Text=[0036] In electroless plating, the surface of the plastic is etched away using an oxidizing solution.
#Text=The surface becomes extremely susceptible to hydrogen bonding as a result of the oxidizing solution and typically increases during the coating application.
#Text=Coating occurs when the polyolefin component (post-etching) is immersed in a solution containing metal ions, which then bond to the plastic surface as a metal layer.
#Text=[0037] In order for electroplating (electrolytic plating) to be successful, the polyolefin surface must first be rendered conductive, which can be achieved through electroless plating.
#Text=Once the polyolefin surface is conductive, the substrate is immersed in a solution.
#Text=In the solution are metallic salts, connected to a positive source of current (cathode).
#Text=An anodic (negatively charged) conductor is also placed in the bath, which creates an electrical circuit in conjunction with the positively charged salts.
#Text=The metallic salts are electrically attracted to the substrate, where they create a metal layer.

#Text=As this process happens, the anodic conductor, typically made of the same type of metal as the metallic salts, dissolves into the solution and replaces the source of metallic salts, which is depleted during deposition.
#Text=[0038] The amount of coating that can be deposited by each technique varies.
#Text=Depending on the end use requirements, one technique may be preferable over another.

#Text=Nonetheless, the metal coatings deposited by these techniques will range from about 0.003 .mu.m for a single layer to 100 .mu.m for a multi-layer coating, preferably from 0.006 .mu.m for a single layer to 75 .mu.m for a multi-layer coating, and more preferably from 0.01 to .mu.m for a single layer to 50 .mu.m for a multi-layer coating.
#Text=The metal in the recycled metallized polyolefins varies from about 0.05 to about 5 wt. %.
#Text=[0039] The most common metal coating applied to polyolefins is aluminum.
#Text=Less common coatings are trivalent chromium, nickel, and copper.
#Text=Even less common coatings are, but not limited to, tin, hexavalent chromium, gold, silver, as well as co-deposited metals such as nickel-chromium.
#Text=Those skilled in the art will appreciate that these metal coatings are not necessarily pure elemental coatings.
#Text=For example, "nickel" may be nickel-phosphorus or nickel-boron alloy and "copper" may be copper-zinc alloy (brass) or copper-tin alloy (bronze).
#Text=Regardless of whether the metal is or isn't alloyed, the specific metal is still the primary component of the coating.
#Text=It is preferred that the metallic coating contain 70-100% of the named metal, more preferably 80-100% of the named metal, and even more preferably 85-100% of the named metal.
#Text=Those skilled in the art will also appreciate that the surface of the metal layers can be oxidized, and some of the metals, tarnished.
